User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; U; Linux x86_64; en-US; rv:1.9.1.16) Gecko/20101206 SeaMonkey/2.0.11
Build ID: 20101206155213

Steps to reproduce:

Normally when SeaMonkey is configured to used the Software Security Device and is invoked to open a URL (either directly from the command line, or else by clicking on a link in another application (assuming the OS is configured to use SeaMonkey as the default browser)) the following will occur:

1. If SeaMonkey is not already running, it will launch, prompt for the Software Security Device master password, and then once the user closes this dialog (with OK or Cancel), it will open the URL.
2. If SeaMonkey is already running, the URL will simply be opened in a new window or tab.

The first case is problematic if the user attempts to open multiple URLs in quick succession.  For example, say a user has SeaMonkey closed, but is reading mail in an e-mail client.  One of the e-mails has several URLs which the user clicks on, one after the other, in rapid succession.  Another example is the case where a shell script is used to invoke SeaMonkey multiple times in rapid succession to open a series of URLs.


Actual results:

In this case, the Software Security Device dialog will appear once (for the first URL).  For all subsequent URLs, the following dialog will appear: "Close SeaMonkey.  SeaMonkey is already running, but is not responding. To open a new window, you must first close the existing SeaMonkey process, or restart your system."  Once this dialog is dismissed, SeaMonkey will not open the URL it was invoked for, even after the Software Security Device password is entered.


Expected results:

Instead of triggering the "Close SeaMonkey" dialog, SeaMonkey should silently add the URL it was launched for to a queue.  Once the Software Security Device password is entered (or the dialog is dismissed with Cancel), SeaMonkey should open all URLs in the queue in new tabs or windows (according to the user's preferences).
